ING SYSTEM Trip to Lansdowne Affords Students
JOHN'S COLLEGE
Both Mental and Physical Development

The course in Geology I is not
only of scientific and cultural value, but also of great value for
Physical development. This latter fact was very evident last week
when the class took a trip to Lansdowne, a small village outside of
Baltimore, for the purpose of
studying the various geological
formations. In order to observe
all the phenomena of a young
stream it was necessary to clamber through what Dr. Schwartz
characterized as "a p-erfect reproduction of the Grand Canyon of
the Colorado on a smaller scale."
The entire class came out puffing
like veritable steam engines. "It
was also necessary to _run for a
long distance back to the railroad
station in order to make- the 4:30
train to Baltimore. This unaccustomed exertion caused the weary
Party to sink gratefully into the
soft cushions of the parlor car as
the train sped homeward.
The trip was of great interest
to the party, especially in that
they were fortunate enough to discover a small deposit of iron ore,
of a grade known as "hematite."
and also a bed of lignite, a form
of coal which has not yet completely hardened. Dr. Schwartz
was helped in conducting the
Party by Dr. Hall, an assistant
instructor in Geology.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 26, 1923

GEOLOGY CLASS COMBINES C. & P. ENGINEER TELLS A. I. MAJOR GAREY INSTALLED
E. E. OF NEW SWITCHAS PRESIDENT OF ST.
SCIENCE WITH ATHLETICS
ING SYSTEM Trip to Lansdowne Affords Students
JOHN'S COLLEGE
Both Mental and Physical Development

The course in Geology I is not
only of scientific and cultural value, but also of great value for
Physical development. This latter fact was very evident last week
when the class took a trip to Lansdowne, a small village outside of
Baltimore, for the purpose of
studying the various geological
formations. In order to observe
all the phenomena of a young
stream it was necessary to clamber through what Dr. Schwartz
characterized as "a p-erfect reproduction of the Grand Canyon of
the Colorado on a smaller scale."
The entire class came out puffing
like veritable steam engines. "It
was also necessary to _run for a
long distance back to the railroad
station in order to make- the 4:30
train to Baltimore. This unaccustomed exertion caused the weary
Party to sink gratefully into the
soft cushions of the parlor car as
the train sped homeward.
The trip was of great interest
to the party, especially in that
they were fortunate enough to discover a small deposit of iron ore,
of a grade known as "hematite."
and also a bed of lignite, a form
of coal which has not yet completely hardened. Dr. Schwartz
was helped in conducting the
Party by Dr. Hall, an assistant
instructor in Geology.
